previewPlan.name: eSports - 2:1 - Moderate Volume
previewPlan.description:
#### eSports - 2:1 - Moderate Volume

The first step in your journey to getting faster!

​

If you are in need of any technical help or want to know more about the training terms used in this plan check out the [Wahoo SYSTM Help Center.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenter)

​

Have a more specific question that isn't addressed in the Help Center? Head over to our [forum](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/) to see if your question has been answered, or just post it for yourself.

​

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Chores
prospects.description:
If you want a do-it-all session that will maintain and improve nearly every aspect of your fitness, _The Chores_ is just the ticket. This workout features 3 sets of intervals. Each set combines a series of 40-second efforts with 20-second recoveries, followed by an immediate transition to a sustained effort just below threshold. These short efforts with minimal recovery deplete your anaerobic gas tank, forcing your body to get better at producing power aerobically. This combination will help improve your Anaerobic Capacity, (AC) your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and your Functional Threshold Power (FTP), all in just under an hour.

​

At the start of each set, your body starts to dip into your anaerobic reserves to help hit the high-power targets. Your body then starts to ramp up your oxygen intake in order to produce more of the power requirements aerobically. With such short recovery time between these efforts, your AC is steadily drained through each set. By the time the last short interval arrives, your body will be forced to produce almost all of that power aerobically, which will push your lungs to their very limit.

​

This is the optimal time to stress your body’s ability to produce power at threshold. With your AC depleted (and your lungs and heart working near maximal capacity), the shorter sustained efforts that would normally be a piece of cake will have a bit more...sting. No matter what your preferred discipline, terrain, or distance, this session will make you fitter and faster.

​

Featuring exciting, on-bike camera footage from the Velon Hammer Series, _The Chores_ will make you earn your keep.

prospects.name: French Pyrenees: Lac de Cap de Long
prospects.description:
Set in the heart of the Hautes-Pyrénées, this ride starts at Saint-Lary-Soulon and explores the sensational Route de Lac, finishing at the 2,160m summit of Lac de Cap de Long. The 22km climb is long, so we break it up into three sections for you. First, you'll have a nice long warm-up to ride into the village of Fabian. Once the proper climb starts, you'll ramp it up to a range between 70-90% threshold and hold it there. Toward the end, you'll start to work hard and finish off with an all-out assault on the summit. Along the way, you'll find out how the local wool is processed, how a network of ancient towers protected the region, why one house is covered in flowers, and what happened to all the local brown bears.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3778259865)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Chasing the Sun
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Fresh from a sold-out tour of UK cinemas, Chasing The Sun is the new documentary film from 2x BAFTA-winning director Michael B.Clifford. It explores extraordinary personal stories of ordinary cyclists taking on iconic endurance event Chase The Sun, revealing the power of the humble bicycle to transform lives and help save the planet.

The film features contributions from broadcaster and ITV’s voice of the Tour de France Ned Boulting, author and blogger Jools Walker, Turner Prize-winning artist Sir Richard Long and 4x Mountain Bike World Champion Tracy Moseley.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Fight Club
prospects.description:
A full remastering of one of our earliest sessions (the original is still available to those of you who are Knights of Sufferlandria), Fight Club is scrappy, messy, and unpredictable. Like a real bike race, you're working hard to stay with the leaders while fending off attacks and doing your best to make the race by attacking as well.

​

With significant time spent at power well above your threshold, this is a solid session to improve your Anaerobic Capacity. The fact that all those surges take place during sustained efforts right around threshold makes this one of the most difficult (yet beneficial) workouts in The Sufferfest Library. Repeated surges followed by sustained riding near your threshold stress your body's ability to clear metabolites (like lactate) and your mental ability to “deal” with the extreme discomfort all those metabolites cause. You're going to come out of this one a bit battered but a lot stronger for it.

prospects.name: Catalunya: Costa Brava Coastline
prospects.description:
Today we’re going to be riding one of the most incredible roads of Spain's Catalan region, going from St Feliu de Guíxols over to Tossa de Mar and hugging the Costa Brava coastline the whole way. Continually undulating we’ll hit each of the eight rolling climbs hard, working at low cadence with high intensity to build strength. Mike will keep you focused on good form, though, and make sure you keep the power down on all the way over each summit.

​

It wouldn't be an On Location ride, though, if we didn't have a look at the scenic attractions along the way, though, so get ready for craggy rocks, turquoise clear waters, and a few opportunities to delve into the Costa Brava’s finest as we find out more about the region along this 21km route.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2967787441439728434)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Adventure For All 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): As one of Wahoo's close partners, Adventure For All's mission is to guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.Together we will guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.

​

**Experience the Adirondacks:**

Join four exceptional athletes in the Adirondack mountains on the adventure of a lifetime. These athletes challenge themselves, conquer fears, and demonstrate their ability to overcome obstacles, proving to themselves and the world they can achieve anything.

​

**Finish:**

Witness Riley, a remarkable young man with Autism and Tourette's, as he pedals beyond expectations to conquer the challenging 31+ mile Big Sugar gravel bike race. This isn't just a story about cycling; it's a journey of courage, hope, and the shattering barriers. With the unwavering support of his mom and the dedicated team at Adventure For All, Riley's adventure redefines what's possible, turning every pedal stroke into a victory for him and everyone who believed in his endless potential.

​

[**Find out more about Adventure For All**](https://adventureforall.org/)

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 4
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Look For Things Where You Can Find Them
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2025): This film is a visually stunning endurance sports film that reimagines what it means to swim, bike, and run. Professional triathlete Eric Lagerstrom sets out on a summer of self-discovery across Colorado, Arizona, and British Columbia, reconnecting with the curiosity that first pulled him into the sport.

Along the way, he rides remote gravel roads with endurance legend Heather Jackson, dives into icy open water with Olympic gold medalist Simon Whitfield, and runs high alpine ridgelines far from any race course. Together, they explore a deeper purpose in sport—one rooted in wonder, not competition.

Shot across three breathtaking locations, this is triathlon like you’ve never seen it: wild, creative, and free.

This is multi-sport without rules. Movement without limits. Adventure without a stopwatch.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Cadence Drills (Builds/Holds/Single Leg)
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

The last drill, Single Leg Efforts, ask you to unclip one leg and ride at a steady, single-legged effort. This forces you to pull up on the pedal instead of just pushing down and ensures maximal muscle awareness and engagement. This workout is best done while riding indoors on a trainer because even small variations in terrain can affect your ability to properly execute this workout. The majority of this workout is done in heart rate Z1/2 /// 50-75% of threshold /// RPE 2-5. You should keep the effort level below threshold (heart rate Z4, 100% of threshold, RPE 7-8) during the max cadence efforts.

​

WORKOUT GOALS:

- To improve stillness and stability at high cadences.
- To improve muscle fiber engagement for improved efficiency at all cadences.
- To increase maximum cadence.
- To make that pedal stroke as smooth as butter.

CADENCE TARGETS:

- Warm-up 80-90rpm
- Build: 90-150rpm
- Hold: 115rpm
- Single Leg: 85rpm

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

​

**Warm Up**

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70%

3 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 3

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 23 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Cadence Build: 30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- Starting at 90RPM Build to Max RPM -- Max Power is NOT Goal

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Cadence Hold: 45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- <100% FTP -- Highest RPM you can hold without Bouncing

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only -- <50% of FTP

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only, Opposite Leg -- <50% of FTP (100% of FTP with both legs = 50% of FTP

with one leg)

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Attacker
prospects.description:
Being able to finish strong comes from properly pacing your efforts and preparing to finish strong. This session is all about improving those abilities. For just over 50 minutes, you'll tackle five different 6-minute long, progressive efforts that start just below FTP and finish well above it for the final minute.

​

The real challenge of this workout is the limited 1-minute recovery sections between each effort. You’ll want to savor every second of those short recoveries. This workout will help improve your FTP and improve your ability to recover while pushing just under your threshold for the first half of each effort. You’ll also learn to manage your pacing and put out power above your threshold after holding steady just below that breakpoint.

​

Riders with sustained weakness will benefit greatly from this workout, as will anyone looking to push up their FTP.

_Attacker_ is quite similar to the SUF workout, _Defender._ However, the efforts within each interval are 2-minutes shorter, and instead of starting harder and backing off like in _Defender,_ the efforts in this session start controlled and keep squeezing harder and harder until the end.

prospects.name: Blender
prospects.description:
A smorgasbord of Suffering, this session has it all. Originally created in Coach Sir Neal Henderson's Penn State dorm room in 1992, it's his weapon of choice for bringing the pain (shakes).

​

What's in the Blender? First, a variety of longer efforts build sustained power while also making sure you're sufficiently fatigued. This initial beatdown is necessary to ensure you get the maximum benefit from _Blender_'s infamous 'Pain Shakes.' Three sets of these little devils help you develop a supernatural ability to recover from big efforts. The bonus is that you also beef up your ability to produce high-end power, building Anaerobic Capacity and Maximal Aerobic Power simultaneously.

​

The threshold efforts at the end are the bitter cherry on the sundae, improving your body's ability to produce aerobic power and helping make sure your FTP will get the same boost as your AC and MAP. A rising tide of lactic acid raises all boats. Oh, and clocking in at one hour and 40 minutes, Blender will also help whip your endurance into a frenzy.

prospects.name: The Last Rider
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2022): The heroic true story of American cyclist Greg LeMond, considered to be one of the greatest cyclists of all time, who defied the odds for one of the most triumphant comeback stories in sporting history. The first, male American to win the Tour de France, LeMond came back from the brink of death to beat his famed rivals in the historic and nail-biting race at the 1989 Tour de France.

Directed by Alex Holmes and featuring exclusive interviews with LeMond and his wife Kathy as well as, never before seen footage, The Last Rider is an exhilarating portrait of one of the greatest athletes of our time.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: AC: 6 x 45s
prospects.description:
There's no getting around the fact that this is a profoundly unpleasant session that will leave your legs feeling like jelly. This session is similar to The Trick, with a few differences. On the plus side, all of the efforts are 15-seconds shorter than those in The Trick. To make up for this, we added two more intervals to this session, bringing the total to 6. That means by the end of this session you will have plowed through 4.5-minutes of AC work.

This workout is one of the few sessions that we do NOT recommend you complete in ERG mode if you are on a smart trainer. The goal is to hold onto the highest power you can for the full 45-seconds. Inevitably in the later sets, your power will dip before you reach the end of the interval. What we want is for you to complete every effort having given everything for 45-seconds. We don't want ERG mode grinding you to a halt because you cannot maintain the (ridiculously) high power targets. Even if you drop down below FTP in the final 10-seconds of these efforts, as long as you are going flat out, you are doing it correctly.

Just take this session one interval at a time, and focus on giving your all for this one effort. You can worry about the others when you get to them. If you finish this session without swearing, then you didn't go hard enough!

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <70

45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <90

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105

45 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- HR >105

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 6

Rest Between Sets: 5 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Effort: 45 seconds @ RPE 9.5 -- 150% of FTP -- HR >105

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

4 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Hammer Chase 1
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Max WALSCHEID (Germany / Team Sunweb)

**Event:** The Chase stage of the Hammer Series in Stavanger, Norway.

**Mission - "Locomotive":** The Velon Hammer race consist of three stages: the Hammer Climb, Sprint and Chase; all of which take place on a short circuit. The Chase is a pursuit version of the Team Time Trial, and is the final stage in the race. The team with the most points starts first, with the other teams following at set intervals. Your job is to help your team chase down the leading team, make up the time deficit and take the overall win. You'll have to dig deep into your suitcase of courage and leave it all on the road to make up the gap. Do you have what it takes to lead your team to victory?

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Phil wins the Tour
prospects.description:
Join Phil Gaimon in his bid to “win the Tour” as he takes on France’s most iconic mountains—The Tourmalet, Mont Ventoux, Alpe d’Huez and Galibier. This session captures the feel of those legendary ascents with 4 x 10-minute descending threshold intervals. Each one starting above threshold before easing down, forcing you to pace smart, clear the burn, and stay locked in until the summit.

​

Between climbs, you’ll get some recovery—time to spin the legs and imagine soaking in the views (or raiding a French bakery, Phil-style).

​

Physiologically, you’ll build muscular endurance, improve your ability to process oxygen, and train your body to go deep without breaking. Mentally, you’ll sharpen pacing skills and resilience—the hallmarks of any great climber.

prospects.name: Clobber
prospects.description:
The 3x25-minute sub-threshold workout is one of the most classic interval sessions out there, so prepare for a trip to the northern Painlands for this FTP-builder. The reason the 3x25 sub-threshold workout is so popular is that it is easy to follow, helps teach good pacing, and gives you a great threshold training stimulus.

​

In this case, you're looking at three, (roughly) 25-minute blocks at around 90% of your FTP, an effort we refer to as "Sub-Threshold". Many refer to this intensity as "Sweet-Spot", but we prefer Sub-Threshold, as the real key is to never let your power creep above your FTP. Staying just below threshold ensures that your effort remains at an intensity you know your body can handle but that is close to what would not be sustainable.

​

The only way you're going to make it through three of these efforts is if you pace yourself properly. Everyone feels just fine for the first 5 minutes of the first effort, and are often tempted to go harder. Don't be that person. More often than not, that person blows up spectacularly in the second interval, unable to finish the session. Or they have to ride that second interval at lower power, turning it into a Tempo session, which is not the goal.

​

Getting a sense of how these efforts "bite" towards the end is vital to learning how to pace yourself over longer steady-state efforts; whether that's a time trial, local climb, breakaway, triathlon, or even a good old fitness test. In each of those cases, the pacing is key. Learning how your perceived effort can steadily climb even though your power remains unchanged is critical to good pacing.

​

So how do you know if you are doing this one right? As we said, the first 5 minutes should feel relatively easy. Around that 5-minute mark, your heart rate should stop climbing, and settle into 2-5% below your Lactate Threshold Heart Rate (LTHR). If your heart rate is climbing for the entire effort and goes above your LTHR, then you are going too hard.

If you hit the 10-minute mark, your legs feel fine, and your heart rate is still in Zone 3, then you aren't going hard enough.

If you've never done a session like this before, you can consider only doing the first 20-minute effort, or even sticking to just the first 15 minutes of each effort. There's no shame in building up to this full session, so don't be afraid to pause and fast forward as needed.

​

Nailing this session is really about getting in tune with your body and understanding what the edge between a sustainable and an unsustainable effort feels like. Not being able to complete this workout is fairly common, so don't beat yourself up if you can't make it through the first few times. As long as you come away from this session with a better understanding of how to pace longer efforts, you've improved as an athlete.

prospects.name: Across the Mountains
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): _Across the Mountains_ follows legendary cyclist Michael Cotty through two different adventures. The first, _Les Alpes_, is the story of Mike's non-stop ride from Evian-Les-Bains to Nice across the heart of the Alps: a journey of 677km with 17 mountain passes and more than 16,000 meters of climbing. The second, _The Road to Mont Blanc_, sees Mike tackle a 1,000 km non-stop journey across 21 mountains in the Dolomites, Eastern and Swiss Alps before finishing at Mont Blanc. Featuring never-before-seen footage and exclusive commentary by Mike Cotty himself.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

​

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 4 Pt 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024):

**Episode 4: Setting An Example**

In Episode 4 we arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO and start to settle in before race day. We pre ride the course, pick up packets and find some nerves. In our final athlete feature we dive into what drives Kristen Myers? How does the super mom do it all and still find time to train? This episodes is all about the final preparations before race day.

​

**Episode 5: Mind Over Matter**

In our last episode, we reach the culmination of all our riders hard work and arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO for the SBT GRVL race. Do they have what it takes to finish 125 miles with less than 6 months of training? Each person will battle their own self doubt as the gun goes off for the final time this season.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: Running With Wolves
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): Cyclingnews Films were granted access to Quick-Step Floors, a team that calls themselves 'The Wolfpack', to follow riders and staff throughout the three weeks of the Tour, with interviews and behind the scenes footage as the team battled it out in the biggest and toughest sporting event on the planet.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

prospects.name: Tempo Alternating: 1 x 40
prospects.description:
This hour long workout is great for the days that you're looking for an aerobic stimulus with just enough up-tempo effort to wake up the nervous system and feel a little more alive! This session has you at 85% of FTP for six minutes, which is mid-tempo effort, then drops you down to 75% of FTP for four minutes of "recovery." Unfortunately, these recovery intervals aren't the really easy kind that we all love. No, today you'll have to maintain a high aerobic effort which requires you to keep some pressure on rather than getting an easy recovery spin. So make sure you're well fueled and hydrated for this one!

​

**Warm Up**

6 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 4

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

Work: 6 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

Steady: 4 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Strade Bianche 1
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Tosh Van der Sande of Belgium

**Event:** Strade Bianche

**Mission - "The Scout":** Welcome to the famous white roads of Tuscany: dusty, unpredictable, and unbelievably hilly. You got in the early break to take the pressure off your teammates. By giving them a bit of a rest early on they'll have a better chance of making a move as the race winds towards the iconic finish in the picturesque hill town of Sienna. Your job is to make sure everybody in the break works well together to maintain a gap and hold off the peloton for as long as you can. The other teams' star riders are breathing down your neck. How long can you keep them at bay?

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: G.O.A.T.
prospects.description:
This session is all about high-torque efforts, very similar to the efforts you would experience riding up the steep slopes of Mt Sufferlandria. While these efforts are short and the intensity isn’t too high, the low cadence targets combined with minimal recovery will leave some begging for the high-cadence sprints of _The Omnium_. High-torque efforts like these have two primary benefits: improved neuromuscular coordination and increased muscular endurance.

​

During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. High-cadence efforts in something like _Cadence Builds_ are great for teaching these groups to make that switch quickly. These low-cadence efforts are better for teaching ALL of the muscles in your legs to “switch on.” Done properly, you should be pulling with your hamstrings with one leg while the other leg is pushing down with all the force your glutes and quads can muster. If you feel like you are pushing yourself up out of the saddle during harder efforts (like seated sprints), your hamstrings are not being utilized since they should pull you back down into your saddle.

​

The second main benefit is improved muscular endurance. Even though the session is under 45 minutes, **you'll put a similar amount of muscular fatigue into your legs as a steady, multi-hour base ride.** You can almost view this session as hitting the leg press for 8 sets of 100 reps. And just like the weight room, proper form is absolutely key. That means:

- You should focus on pushing down AND pulling back up. You want your glutes and quads activated on the way down and your hamstring and hip flexors activated on the way up.
- To properly engage your hamstrings think about trying to pulling your heel up to your butt when your crank arm is going from 6 o’clock to 10 o’clock.
- Your knees should be tracking straight up and down, no collapsing in or out.
- Your core should be fully engaged to keep your hips steady in the saddle. This will be easier if you are both pushing and pulling during each pedal revolution.

This session is very similar to _Power Station_. Both help improve your muscular endurance and coordination; the biggest difference is the work to rest ratio between the two. While the intervals here are shorter than those in _Power Station_, the decreased recovery duration means fatigue will build faster, especially for those with a weakness in repeated efforts.

Modifying interval length and recovery duration can also be seen between sessions like _Revolver_ and _A Very Dark Place_. Both serve up a healthy dose of MAP/VO2 work, but the overall feeling of those two sessions is different.

If you find that your lower back starts to ache during this session or that you have to start rocking in the saddle to keep the power up, then it’s time for you to get started on the SYSTM Yoga program. Kick it off with “Core Strengtheners ” to make sure your core is just as strong as those legs.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[When to Train with Low Cadence](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/when-to-train-with-low-cadence)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Do As You're Told
prospects.description:
The little voice in your head is telling you to stop. The screams from your legs are nearly deafening. But you hear none of it. You're following orders to ATTACK.

​

This is the story of two men in a car—your team directors—who guide you to GLORY. Ignore them at your own risk: They will not tolerate insubordination.

​

In this session, you'll tackle two sets of 11 intervals each. The first set has high-intensity efforts with matching recoveries. This pushes your body's ability to recover right to the limit -- just what you need to improve Anaerobic Capacity (AC). The shorter, super-high intensity efforts also help with your Neuromuscular Power (NM). The second set features inverse intervals with opposite efforts and recoveries. This really depletes your body's AC, so you need to rely on your aerobic system. This helps develop your Maximal Aerobic Power.

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Cash Register
prospects.description:
Over/under intervals, where you alternate going just below and just above threshold, are the foundation of many classic workouts. Cash Register is an adaptation of that idea and comes in the format of a sprint/settle/surge session consisting of 4 intervals that get a little shorter (but not easier) each round.

​

Each interval kicks off with a sprint effort that targets your Neuromuscular (NM) power. Then you settle into a controlled, below-FTP effort that will accelerate the rate at which you can clear lactate from your muscles. You'll finish each effort off with a big surge based on your Anaerobic Capacity (AC). In just 30 minutes, you'll be doing efforts targeting your sprint power, FTP, and AC for an exceptionally well-rounded workout.

​

Support the Wahooligan Tour by [donating to the Davis Phinney Foundation](https://secure2.convio.net/dpf/site/TR?pg=pfind&fr_id=1391) and their programs to help people living with Parkinsons.

prospects.name: No Place Like Home
prospects.description:
Have you been riding, but not riding too hard? Have you been putting in lots of easy and endurance rides but not much intensity? Are you ready to bring intervals back into your routine, but not quite prepared to face up to a session like _Nine Hammers_ or _The Shovel_? Then this is the session for you.

​

If you love _Recharger_ then you're going to tough love_ No Place Like Home_ - the perfect re-introduction to a little bit of hard work. It will wake up your legs, lungs and mind, reminding them what it means to dig deep but without really working too hard or for too long. The workout is expertly designed by Wahoo's Head of Sports Science, Sir Neal Henderson, as a gradual step back into Suffering when self-doubt has taken hold of you and motivation may be low. While you’re riding it, you'll soon realize that you're stronger than you think and that you _can_ work hard. You'll also realize that you really shouldn't have ever left Sufferlandria -- Border Control takes these things very seriously.

​

And when the session is finished? A wave of endorphins kicks in - and if you’ve done it right, you'll feel a sense of elation and a little sting in the legs that reminds you why you were born to Suffer and why there truly is..._No Place Like Home._

prospects.name: French Pyrenees: Lac de Cap de Long
prospects.description:
Set in the heart of the Hautes-Pyrénées, this ride starts at Saint-Lary-Soulon and explores the sensational Route de Lac, finishing at the 2,160m summit of Lac de Cap de Long. The 22km climb is long, so we break it up into three sections for you. First, you'll have a nice long warm-up to ride into the village of Fabian. Once the proper climb starts, you'll ramp it up to a range between 70-90% threshold and hold it there. Toward the end, you'll start to work hard and finish off with an all-out assault on the summit. Along the way, you'll find out how the local wool is processed, how a network of ancient towers protected the region, why one house is covered in flowers, and what happened to all the local brown bears.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3778259865)

​

As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent.
